Because of how his kit was originally designed.

Riot has stated in the past that he was created as a melee botlaner, much in the same way as reworked Mordekaiser but much less forceful.  He has his Q to poke, E for dodging skillshots and probably farming under tower if he gets pushed back that far, and W for blocking important projectile attacks since he doesn't have any way to respond at the ranges in question without having an empowered Q and getting poked too much would force him out of lane and make him unviable.  His two-part passive serves to give him a little extra wiggle room around taking damage and performing all ins while also encouraging him to build like an autoattack-heavy ADC, and his ultimate, while it can be set up by himself, can also be set up by teammates.  His resourceless nature is likely because Yasuo was going to be using his abilities far more than any ADC in order to return poke, farm, and dodge, so his abilities are gated behind long cooldowns (wind wall, and yes, it is on a long cooldown relative to a lot of basic abilities) low cooldowns but long on-target cooldowns (sweeping blade) and the need to stack it up before it becomes relatively long range (Steel Tempest).

Of course, people found that his kit was far stronger in the mid and top lane and moved him there, where his kit can cause more problems for his opponents, but I'd assume that's the origin of his resourceless nature.

This sounds about right from what I remember of when Yasuo was released.

Riot has wanted to make melee botlaners work for a while now but it has never stuck because Ranged Carry + Support is just too powerful. This is because melee champs have been weaker than ranged champs since LoL was in Beta and they need to have all kinds of special buffs and overpowered numbers/overloaded kits to make them even worth playing. Literally, at the start you were hurting your team if you didn't pick a 5 Ranged Champs comp. So over time melee champs have been buffed to ludicrous degrees to make them even viable - naturally Riot sometimes overdoes it and creates monstrously overpowered Tanky DPS champs.

This has been dubbed "the Irelia Problem" even by Riot themselves since Season 2.

Manaless champs are almost all melee, and it's usually done because melee champs just cannot use their melee basic attacks without getting poked to hell and back if they have to lane against ranged champs. Since ranged champs can poke from a very safe distance for no resource, melee champs get forced out of lane and starved for CS since they have to use their abilities to do anything at all. Since ranged top laners like Ryze and Quinn basically make melee top laners useless, Riot has made a lot of melee champs with no mana bar so they can have a chance in lane phase to spam their abilities to farm up.

***Thus Yasuo, and a lot of other historically problematic melee champs, is just a symptom of the great "Melee vs Ranged Laning Problem" that Riot has been trying to solve since Beta.***

I think his flow should be revamped into a resource. He should have to pay flow to use his W and Q and his E should have a cost when it starts to stack up.

That way if he gets caught in a fight with CC he'd be unable to recharge his flow and run out of casts.

Like... make it so his q doesn't need three uses to ramp up but instead flow, make his windwall be a super short duration normally but become a level 3 windwall with flow and his e could make him dash to his target from a father distance. 

This would obviously need other changes like significantly reducing the cd of his w since it would usually be much weaker than it is now and making it so his shield doesn't require flow but it would also make him more interesting.

> Why doesn't Yasuo have mana?

Auto-attacks are manaless.

All passive auto-attack and on-hit steroids are manaless, even on mana-using champions.

Yasou mostly auto-attacks things to death.

Steel Tempest is basically an AA steroid that's more interesting than just an AS or AD buff. Same thing applies to Riven, Tryndamere, and Aatrox. 
To a larger extent: a lot of manaless champions tend to lean heavily in the direction of auto-attacking with spells. Garen's Judgement, Rumble's Flame-Spitter, Nidalee's Swipe, Vladimir's tides of blood, etc.
